div.p: Governor Kate Brown ordered all Oregon schools remain closed through April 28th. This decision was made in consultation with the Oregon Health Authority and informed by the recommendations of the Centers for Disease Control as a necessary strategy to slow the spread of the COVID-19 virus and protect our most vulnerable citizens.
As a result, all Oregon City School District school buildings and departments are closed to all public access immediately. At this time, students are scheduled to return on April 29th.

In the meantime, it is essential we all do our part to keep safe by staying home and practicing social distancing and good respiratory hygiene whenever out. This global health crisis has quickly disrupted our lives, and it is hard for all of us to process. I know it is a source of great stress for all families.
As an organization, Oregon City School District is committed to supporting all students and families during this closure period, as well as serving as a community resource.
We will continue to provide breakfast and lunch at designated sites through April 28th. Beginning March 30th, we will expand services to include additional locations.

div.div: Has anyone in Oregon been diagnosed with COVID-19?

div.p: As of this message, there are many cases of COVID-19 in Oregon. You can review statewide numbers on the Oregon Health Authority website.

div.div: How can families and schools help to slow or stop the spread of viruses, including COVID-19?

div.p: It is essential we all do our part to keep safe by staying home and practicing social distancing and good respiratory hygiene whenever out.
We are prepared to provide supplemental learning opportunities for all students. An announcement about how to access the resources will be sent to families on Friday, March 20.

div.div: The CDC is recommending non-pharmaceutical interventions. What does this mean?

div.p: To slow the spread of COVID-19, and other respiratory infections (including flu and pertussis), families, students and staff can take every day non-pharmaceutical interventions, including:

li.a: Wash hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.

ul.li: Use a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.
Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands.
Practice good respiratory hygiene, covering coughs and sneezes with your elbow or a tissue that is then thrown away, followed by washing your hands.
Students with a fever should stay home from school.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipes.
Get your annual flu vaccine (to protect against flu).

div.div: What does the extended closure mean for graduating seniors?

div.p: At this time, we do not know the exact implications of this extended closure on seniors slated for graduation this spring. The Oregon Department of Education is actively working on this matter, and additional details are expected soon. It is important to remember that all schools in the state and many across the country are in the same situation.

div.div: What should I tell my child about the virus — if anything?

div.p: Families can check out the resources available at Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) and National Public Radio (NPR):

ul.li: Coping with Stress During Infectious Disease Outbreaks (PDF).

div.div: Why doesn’t the district move to online learning?

div.p: The district is not prepared to go 100% online at this time. Not all of our students have access to technology devices or have access to the internet. Additionally, some classes require a hands-on experience, nor does online learning allow for effective personalized support for students with enhanced needs.
The Oregon Department of Education does not recommend schools close and transition to an online distance model unless the district can ensure each of the considerations below can be met.
These include, but are not limited to:

ul.li: Ensuring all students in the school or district will have equal access to the learning and required materials, including technology.

Ensuring the online learning system can effectively support the district’s different learning and teaching needs, including the ability to provide differentiated instruction as well as one-on-one support for students who need it. Regardless of where the learning is happening, supports identified on a student’s Individualized Education Program (IEP) must be provided if the district is operating.
Ensuring the requirements of full-day kindergarten are met.
Ensuring students can access the assessments associated with dual credit coursework.
Providing training to staff, students, and parents and guardians on how the system works and what expectations the district has.
The ability to track the attendance of both students and staff.
Ensuring the systems in use are secure and will not allow for the release of protected student or staff information.
The ability to provide school meals.

div.p: Taking a traditional school environment online is not a simple task. Oregon City Schools, and most districts in the state, are unable to meet the above criteria at this time.
Oregonian article about why the Coronavirus won't lead to online classes.

div.div: Will the 2019-20 school calendar be changed or extended?

div.p: We expect more guidance soon from the Oregon Department of Education about school calendars. It isn’t yet certain how the remaining school calendar may be altered.

div.div: What does the closure mean for athletic practices, games, and other extracurricular activities?

div.p: All athletic and extracurricular activities are canceled through April 28. This includes all meetings, practices, plays, concerts, competitions, etc. Spring athletics are canceled through April 28; more information is expected soon from the Oregon School Activities Association.

div.div: What if I have additional questions?

div.p: The Oregon Health Authority has a robust webpage with answers to additional COVID-19 questions and answers. Visit their Frequently Asked Questions page for more information.

div.div: What if I am an employee of the district and have a Human Resources question?

div.p: Our human resources department has a robust FAQ page for employees to review.
